page.title: 10Water Wheels - Fal Valley
page.content: The use of{water wheels}for industrial purposes was widespread in the region. Often shafts would transmit power up to a mile from the site of the wheel. Three remain visible in the Fal Valley north of St.Stephen. The most accessible is close to where the road to{Meledor}crosses the{Fal.}The wheel is concealed in trees to the west of the river on the north side of the road. This is adjacent to{Melbur Mill} now used for loading tanker lorries from hoppers. Rather more than a kilometre to the north and west of Treviscoe are two further wheels which are on opposite sides of the Fal surrounded by intensive clay workings. They are difficult to find without help and permission for access needs to be obtained from English China Clays. The disused railway along the banks of the Fal is also owned by ECC.
